summary: influenza A(H7N9) virus has caused two major epidemics of human infections since emerging in early 2013. the first epidemic occurred in the spring of 2013 in eastern china [1, 2], while the second epidemic occurred over the winter of 2013–14 in eastern and southern China. more than 80% of confirmed H7N9 cases reported exposure to live poultry or a live poultry market prior to symptom onset. the virus has low pathogenicity in poultry, unlike highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus. it is challenging to control the transmission of H7N9 from poultry to humans. permanent closure of LPMs has been proposed in some of the cities affected by H7N9. izability of the study, we used mobile phone surveys in Guangzhou and door-to-door surveys in zijin. we investigated human exposure to live poultry or LPMs, risk perception, psychological and behavioral responses to the outbreak, and attitudes towards control interventions on the H7N9 epidemic. demographic characteristics were analyzed for each survey and compared with chi-squared tests. population levels of anxiety, exposure to live poultry or LPMs, perceived risk of infection with H7N9, behavioral responses to H7N9, and attitudes towards LPM closure were compared. urban respondents in the first survey reported purchasing an average of 36.5 live poultry in the past year. respondents in the second survey reported an average of 26.7 live poultry purchased in the past year. the proportion of respondents who would always touch live poultry declined considerably from 50.2% in the first survey to 20.6% in the
